1. Create a file that's encoded with UTF-16 LE (New-ModuleManifest will do this for you)
2. Add it to Git.
3. Make a change to the file.
4. View the diff in VS Code.
5. Get a result that looks like this:

data.title: Version 1.2.2 / Updates not available in Ubuntu 16.04 via repo
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1-1493934083
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install code [Manually](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux) 
2. Open terminal, type: `code`
3. VS Code will show an update is available.
4. In terminal type: 
```
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get upgrade

```
5. It tells this:

> code is already the newest version (1.12.1-1493934083).

6. Opening code still shows the message.

data.title: Incorrect result after replacing content of multiple files
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1 (1.12.1) f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4 (16E195)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Assume domain A is  `defg` and domain B is `mnop`.
1. replace domain A with domain B in multiple files, in my case there are 337 files with 1200+ matches),
2. 1 replaced result in only 1 replaced file is incorrect.
The related string is  'abc`defg`hijk' ,
 the result should be 'abc`mnop`hijk', 
but it became 'abcde`mnop`jk'

data.title: Allow Extensions To Contribute Language Specific Settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Problem**
To my knowledge, there is no well supported way for an extension to contribute language specific settings, like so:

```json
    "[markdown]": {
           "amazingExtension.enableUnicornMode": false
     }
```

This actually works, but has some major issues:

* There is no way to specify a language specific setting in the contributes section's schema
* Entering the above configuration produces a warning for users
* To retrieve the setting, you have to write:

```ts
workspace.getConfiguration().get('[markdown]')['amazingExtension.enableUnicornMode']
```

**Proposals**
* Allow extensions to mark settings as being valid language specific settings.
* Add apis for better working with language specific settings

data.title: 'Go to Definition' doesn't always work when using tsconfig.json paths
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Given a tsconfig.json with paths setup like:
```json
"baseUrl": ".",
"paths": {
  "editor/*": [
    "editor/*"
  ],
  "common/*": [
    "common/*"
  ]
}
```

Pressing F12 will not `Go to Definition` when the definition is in a file from the same folder under `editor/*`. 

```js
// editor/tools.js
export function someFunc() {}
```

```js
// editor/myEditor.js
import { someFunc } from 'editor/tools.js'; // 'Go to Definition' not working here
```

However F12 works as expected outside of the `editor/*` folder

```js
// common/utils.js
import { someFunc } from 'editor/tools.js'; // 'Go to Definition' works here
```

data.title: Running VS Code unit tests via VS Code fails
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4
- Node: 7.10.0
- NPM: 4.2.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Confirm that tests pass when run via the command line
```
git clone git@github.com:Microsoft/vscode.git
cd vscode
./scripts/npm.sh install
./scripts/test.sh # 3087 passing (12s)
```
2. Open `vscode` folder in VS Code and run the "Unit Tests" target.

Expected tests to pass.

Actual:
```
  3093 passing (11s)
  14 failing
  1) dom hasClass:
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/dom.test.js:13:13)
  2) dom removeClass:
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/dom.test.js:24:13)
  3) dom removeClass should consider hyphens:
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/dom.test.js:50:13)
  4) Builder Build.withElement():
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:99:13)
  5) Builder Build.withBuilder():
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:109:13)
  6) Builder Build.withBuilder() - Multibuilder:
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:119:13)
  7) Builder Build.withElementById():
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:143:13)
  8) Builder withElementsBySelector():
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:151:13)
  9) Builder Builder.addClass() and Co:
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:495:13)
  10) Builder Builder.show() and .hide():
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:610:13)
  11) Builder Builder.showDelayed():
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:620:13)
  12) Builder Builder.showDelayed() but interrupted:
     AssertionError: undefined == true
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:630:13)
  13) Builder $ - selector construction:
      AssertionError: '' == 'myclass'
      + expected - actual
      +myclass
      
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:1225:20)
  14) Builder $ - delegate to #element:
      AssertionError: '' == 'a1'
      + expected - actual
      +a1
      
      at Context.<anonymous> (out/vs/base/test/browser/builder.test.js:1270:20)
```

Also, why is CLI running 3093 tests while VS Code attempts to run 3107 tests?

data.title: Integrated Terminal does not allow clicking on URLs with fewer than two periods in the domain name.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:18:32.269Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|ng-template|Angular|0.1.3|
|bazel-code|DevonDCarew|0.1.4|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|2.0.5|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.4|
|Theme-azure|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-1337|ms-vscode|0.1.4|;

The terminal automatically allows you to hold down cmd (on mac) and click on a string that appears to be a URL. The parser seems to be overly strict as to what constitutes a URL. In this case, it looks to see if there are at least two periods in the domain name. This is often not the case, as debug output could have URLs such as:

http://internal_server/some_path

(Interestingly enough, http://localhost/some_path does highlight so it seems that this one-word domain is special-cased by the parser.)

---

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Open a terminal window inside of VSCode
2. Type the following (without quotes):
`echo http://a.b.c/path` and press ENTER
3. Hold down CMD (on mac, presumably CTRL on Windows) and hover your mouse over the URL. The URL will become clickable.
4. Repeat step 2 and 3 for the following URLs:
`http://a.b/path` (Not clickable)
`http://a/path` (Not clickable)
`http://localhost/path` (Clickable)
`http://internal_server/some_path` (Not clickable)
`http://a:8000/path` (Not clickable)

**Expected:** All the links above should be clickable.

data.title: How to set environment variables before running integrated terminal?
data.body:
My current integrated shell terminal on Windows 10 is a batch file this these contents:

```bat
@echo off

set CHERE_INVOKING=1

C:\Cygwin64\bin\zsh.exe --login --interactive
```

This allows me to start Cygwin's Zsh at the current opened folder path. But this will make it so that the integrated terminal is "wrapped" around a batch script, which has a few issues. For instance, trying to press `Ctrl+D` to terminate the shell, sometimes I get `Terminate batch job (Y/N)?` and it's annoying.

How can I set `CHERE_INVOKING=1` and call `zsh.exe` directly (with `--login` and `--interactive` arguments) with that environment variable set? Is there anyway to do this within VS Code without a batch file?

data.title: Use HTML automatic code formatting method for SVG files
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
```
  Version 1.12.1
  Commit f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b
  Date 2017-05-04T21:40:39.245Z
  Shell 1.6.6
  Renderer 56.0.2924.87
  Node 7.4.0
```

- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Open SVG file with improper formatting (no line breaks, bad tabbing and spacing, etc.)
2. Press Ctrl-Alt-I (in Ubuntu) or the similar commands for other OSes (see list below)

**Expected:** 

Since SVG is essentially the same as HTML, it should be formatted in a similar way to HTML. The keyboard shortcuts should work with SVG files.

**Workaround:** 

- Rename the SVG file to `[Filename].html` 
- Open the file in the editor 
- Press the appropriate keyboard shortcut to format the "HTML"
- Rename the file back to `[Filename].svg`

**Shortcuts for various OSes:**

    VSCode on Windows - Shift + Alt + F
    VSCode on MacOS - Shift + Alt + F
    VSCode on Ubuntu - Ctrl + Alt + I

data.title: Continue comment when enter is pressed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Arch Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open editor in a language that supports comments (say `foo.c`)
2. Type a line that starts with `//`
3. Press `enter`
4. Next line *should* automatically be started with `//` (or at least this should be possible to configure). Instead, the next line is empty.
